qas.question: What effect was rising salinity having on the agricultural productivity of the Sumerian lands?
The salinity of what in the region was long recognized as a major problem?
Poorly drained irrigated soils in an arid climate with a good deal of evaporation is responsible for leaving what?
What did cultivation shift from to salt-tolerant barley during the Ur III phase?
How much did the population of the region decline due to the decrease in crop productivity?
What shifted from the north to the south of Mesopotamia?
What was increasing agricultural productivity in the area?
What crop was more salt tolerant than barley?
What caused the population to decrease between the 21st and 17th century BC?

plausible_answers.text: the population in this area declined

qas.question: What weakened the areas where Akkadian was spoken?

context: This period is generally taken to coincide with a major shift in <b5_0>population<b5_0/> from southern Mesopotamia toward the north. Ecologically, the agricultural productivity of the Sumerian lands was being <a0_0>compromised<a0_0/> as a result of <b6_0>rising salinity<b6_0/>. <a1_0>Soil<a1_0/> salinity in this region had been long recognized as a major problem. Poorly drained irrigated soils, in an arid climate with high levels of evaporation, led to the buildup of <a2_0>dissolved salts<a2_0/> in the soil, eventually <b8_0>reducing agricultural yields<b8_0/> severely. During the Akkadian and Ur III phases, there was a shift from the cultivation of <a3_0><b7_0>wheat<b7_0/><a3_0/> to the more salt-tolerant barley, but this was insufficient, and during the period from 2100 BC to 1700 BC, it is estimated that <b9_0>the population in this area declined<b9_0/> <a4_0>by nearly three fifths<a4_0/>. This greatly upset the balance of power within the region, weakening the areas where Sumerian was spoken, and comparatively strengthening those where Akkadian was the major language. Henceforth Sumerian would remain only a literary and liturgical language, similar to the position occupied by Latin in medieval Europe.
